awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Automated and Optimized Three Dimensional Routing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes the development of new automated routing optimization methodologies, as well as advanced 3D data compression techniques, which will benefit a wide range of industries and applications beyond the initial focus on building construction systems, including civil and infrastructure design, data center design, robotics, path planning, military applications and the semi-conductor industry.  Any industry requiring 3D spatial analysis and/or routing will benefit from the work of this project.  The project will have broader economic and societal impacts due to a substantial reduction in construction materials and labor necessary for new and remodeled buildings.  Carbon reduction, including embodied carbon and operational carbon, is a critical part of all climate change initiatives.  This AI software will result in a meaningful reduction in emissions due to the ability to optimize the use of materials and labor in the construction and operation of buildings.   The proposed technology will address many forms of design coordination and construction waste, dramatically reducing the amount of raw material, labor and construction waste required to construct a building, while simultaneously reducing the cost and time to occupancy of the construction project.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project aims develop a suite of software that automatically routes building services systems through 3D obstructed space achieving a near optimal, clash-free solution. This involves developing a hyper-efficient 3D modeling environment using a process called “low-resolution surface tessellation” (LRST). In lieu of trying to achieve a high-resolution surface, the project will create as rudimentary of a surface representation as possible to minimize the number of data points stored, thereby reducing the size and complexity of the data set necessary in which to compute routes. The project will develop new 3D optimized routing algorithms in the new 3D environment using a combination of mixed integer linear programming, visibility graphs, non-linear reduction, and variable relaxation among other techniques. The resulting technology, if successful, will find the most efficient path from Point A to Point B through a 3D space filled with any nature of obstructions in polynomial time, or better with no conflicts or clashes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded Phase I Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project has advanced automated routing optimization and 3D data compression technologies to address critical challenges in building systems design.  The project has many potential applications to any industry that requires routing of objects or systems through a three-dimensional obstructed space. The Phase 1 research and development focused on developing efficient and accurate methods to automate and optimize the routing of HVAC, plumbing, and other building service systems through complex 3D spaces. These innovations aim to enhance the Architectural, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industry by streamlining design processes, reducing errors, and supporting more sustainable construction practices.  By combining advanced algorithms with innovative data compression techniques, the Phase 1 research results demonstrate the potential for scalable solutions to transform building systems design, while promoting sustainability and operational efficiency.

Key Accomplishments

One of the project’s standout achievements was the proof of concept development of software capable of automating the routing of building service systems, such as HVAC, plumbing, electrical conduits and fire sprinklers through 3D spaces.  While the results are not entirely clash-free in obstruction-heavy environments yet, they demonstrate an impressively high degree of accuracy and efficiency, even under challenging conditions.

The project also made significant strides in the fields of mathematical modeling and algorithmic research. These models achieved near-optimal results for smaller test cases, while scalable approximation models balanced computational efficiency with minimal trade-offs in accuracy.  Additionally, multiple dynamic programming approaches were developed to approximate solutions with significantly reduced computational time, enabling efficient solutions for large-scale problems.  Together, these advancements provide a robust framework for solving computationally intensive challenges, setting the stage for future research into incorporating additional complexities including tight spatial constraints and obstructions.

Another highlight of the Phase I research was the introduction of novel methods of compression by minimizing the data points necessary to represent a space and its obstructions.  This approach dramatically reduces data complexity, enabling faster and more scalable processing for architectural and engineering projects.  Entirely new techniques were developed that reduced file sizes significantly while maintaining geometric fidelity.  These compression methods enhance data storage and integration across platforms, making them essential for handling large and complex projects.

Broader Impacts

The technologies developed in this project have significant implications for improving sustainability and efficiency in the building design and construction practices.  By optimizing material usage and reducing waste, these tools contribute to a meaningful reduction in embodied carbon emissions—a key focus in addressing climate change and promoting sustainable development.  The ability to design systems with greater precision ensures materials and labor are used efficiently, minimizing waste and improving overall project outcomes.  More efficient design of the building services systems will also provide significant improvements in operational efficiency and operational carbon reduction.

Additionally, the innovations in development streamline construction workflows, allowing faster project completion with fewer errors and reduced rework. This not only lowers construction costs but also shortens construction timeframes allowing for quicker building occupancy, delivering substantial added value to stakeholders throughout the construction process. The tools being developed in this project create a foundation for more reliable and efficient routing solutions, enabling the AEC industry to meet the growing demand for sustainable and cost-effective construction practices.

By addressing the long-standing inefficiencies in the AEC industry, and providing scalable solutions, this project demonstrates a clear pathway to improving the environmental, economic, and operational aspects of building systems design.

Future Directions

Building on these successes, future work will focus on continuing to develop the software to improve routing accuracy and construction efficiency further.  A major priority is integrating multiple building systems—such as HVAC, plumbing, fire protection and electrical networks—into a single, unified routing framework to achieve a “clash free” design.

The team will also work on enhancing compression techniques to achieve even higher ratios, while maintaining peak computational performance.  Expanding the scalability of the software will remain a focus, ensuring the technology can handle increasingly complex projects across diverse industries.

Conclusion

The early results of this project demonstrate the potential for advanced computational techniques to tackle real-world challenges in building systems design and beyond. The innovations developed during Phase I establish a strong foundation for further research and development of more advanced tools to support sustainable building design practices, while offering groundbreaking solutions for a wide range of other industries.  By improving routing efficiency, reducing waste, and enabling scalability, these advancements have the potential to drive significant technological and societal progress in many industries.

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2025
Modified by: Gregory R Schnackel
